comments.commentBody:
Love this... My Middle name is Texas and it was the only name I was ever known by until 9-11 laws made me add the first name Clayton, instead of the initial C.
When you name is Texas everyday is a conversation about it... Thanks for writing... Ps. THis is from the NYT a few years ago... Honorable mention...
https://tierneylab.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/04/01/the-story-of-a-boy-named...

I'm so excited. I was working on this puzzle as the 41st in my streak. Took a bit to fill most of it in, but I was close. But I could not finish the bottom center. I really thought my streak would end today.

I was not sure about SCUT and NEUER and kept fiddling around near their crossing. I left it with those correct answers (knowing that is a valid German name spelling and, not being familiar with SCUT work, but I figured maybe it's from 'scuttle'--or something, one of those 'puzzler's intuition' things). After a lot of grief in this area I finally figured I must have a problem elsewhere.

My attention went to "Dragster's grp.", which I had as NHRe. I realized I had no idea what that was, and then questioned "G.I. Wear", which I had as TeeS and OITNB star as TAYLORSCHILLINe (I've never watched it so I had no idea.)

Once I stopped to think what the dragster group would be I hit on National Hot Rod Association, which gave me TAeS for the G.I. wear, which quickly got me to TAGS and TAYLORSCHILLING for the win! Whew! Over 50 minutes, but my streak is alive at 41! :^)
Well done, Dan

Applause for your tenacity and for the way you went about thinking through your snag.

Keep it up!
Thanks all. And Sundays on the bag so I'm setting my sights on 50 now.

A fine piece, Mo :)

Optical delusion, indeed; the Mad Hatter, who's revealed to actually be Bozo each time his mask slips a little, will only be POTUS until his tax records are subpoenaed.

Until then, craven corrupt power-hungry GOP'ers will tolerate anything, as North Korea festers, the Baltic states shudder, and Heritage plans its next meet-and-greet for GOP'ers and Russia's ambassador:

http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2017/03/02/sessions_privately_pai...

It is impossible to imagine the hue and cry that would arise from these very same groups, if a Democrat were POTUS, and flying off to Florida for the 4th weekend in 42 days, instead of staffing the administration:

http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/25/politics/donald-trump-cabinet-vacancies/

One thinks that surely even DJT apologist Thiel recognizes the difference between incompetence/dereliction, and ' disruption ', since the primary function of government has become the delivery/administration of services, not innovations of markets.

Besides, one need only look at the Americans who suddenly acquired health insurance under the A.C.A. to know that markets are not the end all/be all to provide consumers with all the choices needed - it is a textbook example of markets providing only what fits certain business models, proving the need for regulation(s).
I continue to shake my head about the Republican party being cowards, thugs, indecent and immoral.

"“He became president of the United States in that moment, period,” Jones said, calling it “one of the most extraordinary moments you have ever seen in American politics, period.”"

Extraordinary, all right. I don't think anyone has ever seen an American president callously use a grieving widow as a prop, measuring applause for a needless death he refused to take responsibility for, instead blaming "his generals" after before trying to palm it off on President Obama.

Sorry, one hour does not a president make. As proof of the temporary exception Trump made to his usual style, this morning we were treated to a particularly vicious accusation about President Obama "wiretapping" Trump Tower. I don't know which was worse, the unfounded, undocumented lash-out or the fact Trump knows so little he doesn't seem to realize there's a law against President ordering wiretapping.

I don't know if the nation is lucky or unfortunate that Trump can't stay out of character for long. If Ms. Dowd is indeed correct that the more Trump sounds like a regular pol the more he can get away with, I don't think we need to worry.

Trump is constitutionally incapable of staying out of character for long, just as W shows no real comprehension of the disaster we call his presidency. Neither has appropriate responses to truth, whether it's using the term "carnage" in an inaugural address, or laughing over real carnage during the Iraq War.
Van Jones is a horrible, intellectually inept creature who plays for pay.
Van Jones should be asked to leave CNN and go to Brietbart where he belongs.

By his naïve and gullible remarks that Trump is now presidential, Van Jones has shown he is undeserving of a leadership role, or any role whatsoever, in progressives' fight against the unhinged monster who occupies the White House.
PHI is the scoreboard abbreviation for the PHI-ladelphia Eagles.
Think of "Is this thing on?" as a comic might say it when his jokes are dying.
Necco makes wafers and the classic candy hearts with the words on them.

"In the end it's about morals. We're not going to let somebody run God out of our country."

God help us if tens of millions of us think that Donald Trump is a moral man.

I understood the article and the comment by the mayor.

The hated federal government is not stopping anybody from leading a moral life.

Conservatives talk about "personal responsibility". How about taking some and stop blaming a nameless, faceless, person in D.C. for your issues? Or is it only fair to complain about "the man" when you live in a rural part of the country and are white?

Millions did indeed vote for Trump in spite of his personal life. They expected that a "billionaire" could wave a magic wand and create a workers' paradise for them.

Their foolishness will cause more than buyers' remorse.
The real question is where is the evidence that anyone is attempting to run God out of the country?

I can't let this stand unchallenged. The Left does not reject God entirely, as you claim. SOME on the Left are self-avowed atheists, but the Left includes people of all faiths who regularly attend religious services, support religious charities, and try to live their lives according to moral standards. You don't support your claim in any way, but let me ask you: Should I hold the Right in contempt because SOME on the Right go to church weekly and praise God in public but live entirely unChristian lives abusing women and children, cheat their employees and contractors, lie, hate their neighbor, and show no sympathy for the poor and disabled?

Reconciliation begins when we recognize the humanity in others (as the column suggests) rather than demonize them. It may be very difficult, but it's not complicated.

Affirmative action wouldn't have been needed at all if there weren't racial discrimination. It used to be the law discriminating, now it's "custom" and clever dodges like voter ID. Wake up to reality, Mr. Douthat. Get arrested while Black, try to hail a cab to go uptown while Black, apply for a job with a photo of yourself as Black. Or talk with a cross-section of Black Americans about their day-to-day experiences.
Would you willingly become a black man with a household wealth of $11,200 for ten thousand bucks? I didn't think so.
Or just try being a Harvard educated, former constitutional law professor President while Black

@ Howard - yes I know that in my country of birth even sophisticated researchers say that Americans instantly identify a person's "race" and then practice discrimination based on "race". These researchers should know better.

The families of those men who have been killed for "driving while black" know that the police officer did not determine in microseconds the killed person's "race" but rather caught a glimpse of color and perhaps a ridiculous reason to kill - driving with one light out.

That is why I prefer researchers' definition of racism: acting against a person or group because of some identifiable difference - skin color, religion, etc.

So being killed for driving when black is the price of the basic racism of the killer.
Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com
We have always had Affirmative Action in the US.  It's just that up until the past few decades it always favored white people.

Although mustard is a fine/favorite condiment, we agree with Bruni it doesn't go with omelets - perhaps this is a peculiarity of all us Halloween folks ?

But culinary habits do provide insights/clues to personality, such as when we all learned DJT eats pizza with a knife and fork:

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-sarah-palin-pizza-fail-knive...
Who are "Halloween folks"? Ghosts?

R. Law -

Neapolitans also have been known to eat pizza with a knife and fork, and they are the biggest pizza snobs in the world. In fact, they claim to have invented pizza.

I'll give him a pass on that.

R Law: that's just it....you and other lefties wish to judge Trump as somehow "crazy" or worse, "rich" (spoiled, entitled) because of HOW HE EATS PIZZA.

I've seen people eat it with a knife and fork -- I'VE eaten it with knife and fork -- I've seen people pick up a slice and eat it by hand.

It can be due to the temperature of the pizza -- a VERY hot slice is nearly impossible to hold in your hand, and the hot cheese can burn you -- AND the formality of the restaurant. At home, with a pizza that is not so hot, you can eat out of your hand. At a restaurant, maybe not.

It's just ridiculous to even make an issue out of this.
Curling - a sport in the Winter Olympics

Which we called Iggles when I was growing up there!

Meet me at the Iggle (at Wanamaker's, where my grandmother worked).
http://www.ipernity.com/doc/jonathan.cohen/16566613

I could not be happier if I knew that the president ate steak at every meal. Make that a large, greasy steak, full of saturated fat and floating in cholesterol. Pour on the ketchup, fill the baked potato with butter and wash it down with a few cans of carbonated sugar water. And maybe have fried chicken for dessert. It’s a meal fit for a king, especially one that you’d rather not have hanging around for very long.

Normally, we wouldn’t be critical of a president’s diet. But sometimes the meal is the mirror of the man, and the artless, déclassé or unsubtle food choices can recall for us those qualities in the guy who’s chowing down. I may sometimes do the same, but I’d like people to think that my consumption of Little Debbie Oatmeal Cream Pies was done ironically.

Eating red meat seems an appropriate diet for the president. A man who will deport the undocumented and break up families to make a pointless political point aren’t the kind of people who nibble on cucumber sandwiches and tea cakes.

In this wild, tweet-filled and careening presidency at least we’ve found one area where our POTUS is predictable. There’s no need to ask him what’s for lunch. He’ll have what Putin’s having.

President Clinton had his own cheeseburger fetish, but later became totally vegan because he wanted to live long enough to see his grandkids--that worked. President Obama had his own food indulgences, but he also had Michelle to keep him on a good path with occasional "side trips"--that worked too and will for most people.

This guy will take no advice on any subject, not even about a diet to keep him from keeling over at any time. OTOH, he neither smokes nor drinks alcohol. I think he does not do harmful recreational drugs.

At my (and the current president's) age I find my preferences in everything culinary naturally moderating . My partner makes the veggies while I cook the mains. But I will always hate kale, and brussels sprouts unless roasted with olive oil and salt. Broccoli, you're on probation.

@Gemli: do you seriously think no other President ever ate steak (ketchup or not)?

Do you think Barack Obama -- of the "7 almonds each night" routine -- has never eaten a steak? really? THE PRESIDENT?

Do you utterly fail to remember the terrible eating habits of Bill Clinton? Greasy burgers, yes steaks, lots of meat and cheese, donuts and junk food.

I have no idea if Trump drinks soda pop or not, but I am sure the dogged left-wing press will find out and excoriate him for whatever he drinks.

BTW: Trump is a teetotaller, like Romney. But gee, it's too bad he's not a lush, so you could mock that too.

So YOU can eat Little Debbies, in the privacy of your own home -- but Trump's eating habits mirror his personality? Hypocrite much?

President Clinton did not become vegan -- PRIVATE CITIZEN Bill Clinton had a coronary bypass, and CHOSE to go on a vegan diet. This was long after he left office.

Frankly, he hasn't been the same guy since. He looks miserable, drawn, pale, HUNGRY. I feel sorry for him.

You say President Obama had his own food indulgences (7 almonds?) but WHAT were they? I don't recall any media obsessing on what he ate -- his smoking, perhaps. Not his diet.

And Michelle "kept him on a good path"? HOW DO YOU KNOW THIS? Michelle worked full time; Barack did not. He was a volunteer "community organizer". That isn't a real nor full time job. I'd be very surprised if a working mom did all the shopping and cooking in that household!

The truth is, you don't know what Mr. Obama ate or did not eat. He kept it private, which is his right. When he was called out on his smoking...he apparently kept it private. My guess is he still smokes, he just didn't let people see it.

Smoking is worse for by 100-fold than anything you could possibly eat.

I do not think the South is doing exactly what the North is doing. I think the South is unique in its conflicts. After all, the North finally gained peace after the separation. Darfur is unfortunate but its cause is complex. It is much closer to tribal wars than government sponsored genocide. If the U.S. really cared about human suffering, Darfur would have been that part to split out...not South Sudan. But then, how to feed Darfur would have been a bigger problem.

The cause of existence for the South Sudan is exactly those barrels of oil which the U.S. forfeit when it started sanctioning Sudan decades ago due to a petty conflict in political stance (the Chinese and Canadians happily took over). There are also gold mines in the South. While in Sudan about two decades back, we found many in Khartoum believed that U.S. has constantly been working with rebel groups to separate out the part of Sudan where the oil drills need to be.

Yet, while Khartoum is a legitimate government, the rebels are rebels who had no experience in sorting out conflict of interests. Throughout the conflict with the North, President Bashir has offered peace treaty after peace treaty, only to be broken by the Southern rebels every few years to gain bargaining power.

If we are being honest, I would say the U.S. has seen this coming way ahead of time...but its stakes were too high to leave Sudan alone. Without U.S. support, perhaps the South would live in moderate oppression, but at least in peace.

Someone should help them sue those companies who are extracting resources, leaving money so the the next company can come along and sell the weapons to clear more land so they can extract more. World criminal court, UN sanctions whatever it takes. Pressure from U.S. citizens - ineffective now. Obama tried to stop this kind of thing by regulating it by making them report their payments and activity, but of course as soon as Republicans got in power they stopped the regulations. Sick, greedy.

The independence of South Sudan is not about oil, it is about people who as a group (black and Christian) fought for decades (with little to no help from the US or European governments) to free themselves from domination by the Arab-led government in Khartoum.  Sadly, since this hard-fought independence was achieved, the different ethic groups in South Sudan have been unable to unite and share in the natural resource wealth of the area, but have warred with each other to the detriment of the entire population.

Wow. Christian? Islamic? Suppression? It smells like some kind of crusade down here. Well US intervention didn't help but made things worse. Didn't it? But anyway good for South Sudanese US will allow in only Christian refugees. Isn't that a relief.

Dan,
Here's something for your "I'm so excited" (and to thank you for explaining to Deadline that today's Eagles were not the music group):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8iwBM_YB1sE
Aha — thanks, Dan and Rampiak!

I think those of us who have been the victim of the Scut Farkases of the world have a special place in our hearts for those scenes in "A Christmas Story."
I always enjoyed that his family name (Farkas) is the Hungarian for "wolf," entirely fitting.

Which leads me to the serendipitous observation that Pécs is one of the major cities of Hungary...

A very enjoyable puzzle that I almost finished. Loved the long entries. I've now been doing the NYT daily for about 6 months and am just beginning to crack the Saturdays. If ANYONE LISTENING, any tips on conquering Saturdays? I'm guessing it's just a matter of practice.
Put it down and come back to it, that always helps.

.
Enter no letter before it's time.

Some swear by entering and erasing. But the open space -- "negative space" as Henry Rathvon, Emily Cox, and "Pagan" Kennedy might say -- is where ideas occur. If you fill in a letter, does your eye signal your brain that it might be just a guess at the letter? Does your eye see it as erasable?

I enter each square only if merited. Nothing is to be taken for granted in the themelesses. (The same may be true for parts of the Sunday, although the theme answers give many toeholds on many words.) I may enter 2 squares in a 5-letter word, then come back 'round after I've done other corners of the grid.

Let's face it: Having an A in a word will not assist you in determining that the crossing word is SCUT. It will, in fact, hinder you. Leave that square blank. It may remain blank, or it may get filled in; but meanwhile, you don't have to look at it and believe it to be filled.

Also, make marks. Have meanginful (to you) indicators of different problem clues. "Let" can be a clue referring to tennis, to "allowed", to rentals, etc. So maybe circle that word in the clue. Some other type of clue, maybe you underline. It's your puzzle, your paper.

And NEVER, until you're such a late-week expert that you could edit the puzzles, never think of the clues as "questions" that are being "answered" in the grid!! That false mindset leads to comments like, "I don't know opera". CLues don't ask for knowledge, they ask for letters. Solely. Enter letters.

If you can't think of anything to do that would help, don't blame the lack of help of the color of their skin.

This is an intractable problem. If the UN can't help, and the African Union can't help, there is probably no way we can help. Certainly not by providing arms to one group or another, or handing money to one group or another.

This is heartbreaking and I do not presume to know of any solution. But there is no need for a famine caused by government and rebel troops appropriating humanitarian supplies, this is disgusting and shows that the military and any solution involving supporting military action is counterproductive. The thing that gets me is that history just repeats itself; I remember reading how Machar as a warlord used to misappropriate supplies to feed and his rebels. You would think that at the very least there could be some from the international community just on this level, forget about having a trustee government or some such thing -- just protection of the donated supplies and ensuring that they get to the people they are intended to go to.

By all rights we should have nothing to complain about here or elsewhere, after reading this, but yet we will.  Just another day on earth, I guess.  This really demonstrates how helpless we clearly are.

Instead of TPP-style globalism, developed to consolidate money in the hands of relatively few, we need real, people and needs based globalism.
If catfish can be grown on a large scale in Vietnam it can be used to support those in famine, for example, not just to destroy the American catfish industry. When the profit is not going to the producers in Vietnam and the consumer in the US isn't getting any significant reduction in cost, then directing the fish/ product to Africa at a reasonable cost does a lot of good with the only downside that somebody is not getting the profit.

I can't say that the outcome has been surprising. If anything, it was sadly predictable - when you have thugs (that's what they are; some wearing silly cowboy hats), with absolutely zero experience in governing and who have known nothing except that might wins the day, this is precisely what you get . . .
Gee, I wonder where the cowboy hats came from.

To understand the plight of the South Sudan first look at the neighborhood:
1. Uganda's Museveni refuses to relinquish power
2. Kenya is a poorly functioning kleptocracy
3. Ethiopia is an oppressive dictatorship
4. Central Africa Republic is in the midst of a low level religious war
5. Congo... well the Congo is the Congo - there is an old joke, the only democratic thing about the Congo is the name - The Democratic Republic of the Congo.
That is the neighborhood that nurtured the nation of South Sudan. Not one of them is even capable of providing the technical and political aid needed to rebuild South Sudan's communities after decades of civil war. Ironically, there is one neighbor who may have been able to help. The North. Then again why would they come to the rescue of the South? The South let the western world turned an African quest for political and territorial independence it into a religious war, pitting good Christians (and their Hollywood allies) against evil Muslims. While the truth was always buried somewhere in the murky middle that is African politics. After all that vilification, I doubt the Muslim dominated North will want to see the South succeed as a country, just to prove a point. That is the real tragedy of the South Sudan.
You left out Somalia as one of the regions neighbors. America has a drone war against al Shaab currently underway, and using the country as a "black sight" for interrogations of suspected terrorist.

This sad story only reflects the fact that many places and their people are not ready for forming self governing states.  All these wars, atrocities, and refugees that inundated the West are results of failed states.   There will be no effective solution until people are willing to look squarely into and accept this reality.
